{.medium} - Economics of natural resources has a long history dating back to classical economists like Malthus and the phyisocrats where land is source of wealth - 1960s: Revival of Pigou’s concept of [externalities]{.marker-hl} to describe pollution - 1970s: Are there [limits]{.marker-hl} to growth? [@meadows:1972] - 1980s: Institutionalization of ecological economics with establishment of the [International Society for Ecological Economics]{.marker-hl} in 1988 [@ropke:2004] - Ecological economics addresses the interdependence and coevolution of human economies and natural ecosystems ## Climate in economic policy {.medium} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="20%"} ![](img/sdg13.png) ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} - Ecological sustainability is no explicit goal in traditional economic policy frameworks - Climate and the environment are addressed in several SDGs, like in SDG 7 (clean energy) or SDG12 (responsible consumption & production) - [SDG 13]{.marker-hl}: "Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts" but only vague targets - The UN "Paris agreement" of 2015 is a legally binding treaty to limit the temperature increase to [1.5°C]{.marker-hl} above pre-industrial levels and to reduce global emissions by [43%]{.marker-hl} by 2030. ::: ::: ## Decoupling growth from emissions {.medium} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/decoupling.png) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Attention!]{.marker-hl .secfont} - Consumption-based versus production-based emissions! - These countries represent less than 15% of global population and less than 30% of global emissions! - Global emissions still continue to rise! ::: ::: ## Climate crisis and inequality {.medium} - There is ample evidence of inequality in (consumption-based) greenhouse gas emissions. However, studies typically find emissions inequality being smaller than income or wealth inequality. - 20 global billionaires emit 164,000 tons of CO2e whereof two thirds origin from their yachts only. The global average is 5 tons per capita, thus 20 indiviuals emit 100 tons. [@barros:2021] - In the EU, top 1% of households emit 22 times the per capita climate target of 2.5 tons of CO2e. Only 5% of EU households live within the targets. [@ivanova:2020] - In Austria, the top decile in the income distribution emits 4 times more than the bottom decile. [@theine:2022] ## Global emissions inequality {.medium} ![](img/ghg_ineq.png){height="500" fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @chancel:2023 ::: ## A framework for climate policy {.smaller} ![](img/framework.png){height="500" fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @chancel:2023 ::: # Facets ![](../../data/img/avatar_read.png){fig-align="center" height=350} ::: footer ::: ## What are facets? {.medium} Facets show small multiples (or subplots) for different subsets of data
::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-larger} | Code | Result | |------|--------| | facet_wrap(~continent) | Plot for each continent | | facet_wrap(continent ~ year) | Plot for each continent/year | | facet_wrap(..., ncol = 1, nrow = 1) | Specify grid layout with columns and rows | | facet_wrap(..., scales = "fixed") | Specify fixed axis, alternatively "free_x" or "free_y"| | facet_wrap(..., dir = "h") | Direction of facets, horizontal ("h") or vertical ("v") | | facet_wrap(..., strip.position = "top") | Positioning of the facet labels (strips) | ::: ::: {.aside} Note: [facet_grid()]{.secfont} produces a grid of plots for each combination of variables, even if some plots are empty. ::: ## Create facets by a variable of interest {.medium} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = mpg) + geom_point(aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + facet_wrap(~class, nrow = 2) ``` ![](index_files/figure-html/facets-1.png){width=960} ## Bibliography {.bibstyle} :::footer :::
